Deputy Tierney, of course, treated us to a certain amount of statements that there were conspiracies, that there were actions but he did not tell us what they were. He did not give us any evidence, I submit. The first thing that should be done by the Government, before introducing this Bill, is to give evidence to show that this Bill is a necessity and, having shown that it is a necessity, then we can proceed to consider the utility of the measure for the purpose with which it is alleged to deal. They say there is a conspiracy but I suggest to the Government that the Government after all is but a committee of the citizens of the State and that they have no more right to conspire against the liberty of the citizens, and carry through that conspiracy by force, than any other organisation of the citizens and under this Bill, if it becomes law, the ordinary guarantees and safeties of the average citizen will, to a great measure, disappear.
Will the Deputy tell us how, and where?
Deputy Byrne, of course, is very impatient and, of course, having his locker full of briefs, he has not time to read the Bill.
That is very nasty.

I am prepared to be as nasty to people who have no patience to wait to hear the truth on both sides. I warn Deputy O'Kelly of that. He told us of incidents that, of course, everybody regrets. He told us of incidents that no considerable number of the citizens of this country stand for or are in favour of. But I suggest to him that incidents of a similar nature take place in other countries and there is no panicky legislation of this kind. I suggest to him that he need only do a night's travel and he will find incidents as serious, as grave and as menacing to the State and the citizens of the State, and there is no panicky legislation. I suggest there are other vast and extensive States, Republics, if you like, where incidents just as serious take place, and there is no panicky legislation to meet them. Does it mean that the police organisation and the Detective Division here, who were so very well praised here yesterday, and praised on many other occasions, are unable to deal with the criminal forces and the criminal instincts of some people of this State? If it does, let that failure be confessed, and let some other means be devised to deal with criminal intentions and criminal activities.

MainHeading.P: Now as to the utility of the Bill. Not being willing to discuss Deputy de Valera's speech or Deputy Tierney's speech, I do not propose to be very long in considering this measure. The utility of the matter is very important, and if we are to give it any consideration at all we must consider what is its utility. How does it propose to carry through the object for which it is introduced? How is it proposed to protect jurors? Fiction is full of mystery men who do impossible things on impossible occasions, but the Minister is going to introduce into the Irish State a number of mystery men about whom will hang an atmosphere of mystery and romance. He is going to number twelve, twenty or thirty men, and he is going to have them empanelled in secret. He is going to allow the prisoner the right to challenge, but why should a prisoner challenge number forty-six any more than eighty-two, or why should the prisoner challenge number eighty-one any more than one hundred and fifty if the prisoner does not know whom he is challenging? What is the good of challenging where he does not know whom he is challenging? The State knows exactly who the people are; it knows whom to challenge; it is not going to be guided by numbers. It knows the names of the people; the tags are to be put up for the prisoner, and he has no means of discovering who they are. Having numbered his jurors and empanelled them in secret, so that nobody would know who they are and nobody would be able to do them grievous bodily harm, he proceeds to march them into open court, where they can be recognised. Was there anything more silly ever introduced into a Bill unless it is seriously considered to close the courts against the public and the Press and give admittance to nobody. What is the good of putting numbers on the jury inside and marching them out into the jury-box where they can be recognised? Would the Minister tell us what would be the effect or advantage of it towards the jurors? Of course, perhaps the idea is to close the courts to the public and to close them to the Press. I know the Minister has power to do it, I know he suggests that it is here in the Bill, that on the sworn statement of a police superintendent the Press and the public can be excluded and you take away from the judge any discretion in the matter. You put the entire responsibility on the police officer that everybody is to be excluded from the court, and, having empanelled your jury in private, having destroyed the right to challenge of the prisoner, and having, on the evidence of a police superintendent, cleared the court, you proceed to deal with the prisoner in a democratic fashion! Surely, that is a democratically constituted court by a democratically constituted Government!

I can find no necessity for this Bill, at all events, from what the Minister has told us. He has given us no evidence as to the necessity for the Bill and no demonstration as to how this Bill will effect the purpose it was introduced for. Of course, we are all accustomed to the story of plots, counterplots and such things that have been the stock-in-trade of Governments in this country for ages. One would have hoped that this Government would have departed from that tradition. One would have hoped, when this Government came to this Dáil with the Bill which they say there is a necessity for, that they would produce sufficient evidence in this Dáil to convince the members that there was a real necessity for it, and having proven that there is a necessity for it that they would proceed to show how it is about to achieve the purpose for which it is introduced. I cannot see the necessity for it or even the utility of it when it is put into operation. For centuries we have been endeavouring to demonstrate to foreign people that we were worthy of self-government, but as far as I can see, since the present Government came into office, it has been endeavouring to demonstrate that we are incapable of self-government.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Hogan) Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Hogan)
Speaker.P: I had not the advantage— I have to use the word advantage— of listening to this debate yesterday, but I read the debate in the Press and I listened to portion of it to-day. I do say it is the most disgraceful debate I have ever listened to.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Boland Mr. G. Boland
Speaker.P: You said that about a good many other debates.
I did not.
You did.

I say deliberately it is the most disgraceful debate I ever listened to. The Deputy who has just sat down, Deputy Hogan, of Clare, said that the British in the old days used to make the charge against us that we were incapable of self-government. That is true. He also said that the technique of the British here—he copied Deputy de Valera in that—was to imagine plots, to discover plots. That is quite true. And he said deliberately that that is our technique, that we have discovered a plot that, in fact, does not exist.
(Clare): What I did say, sir, was that one would have hoped that the present Government would have departed from that tradition.

I do not want any hedging in this matter. We seem to have become past masters in hedging in this House. The double-meaning phrase is all over it. I have just been listening to the Deputy. The Deputy who has just sat down stated expressly, and he copied Deputy de Valera, as I will prove afterwards——
(Clare): I did not copy Deputy de Valera. I was not listening to Deputy de Valera.
Neither was the Minister.
(Clare): I do not know what Deputy de Valera said nor do I care.
I claim the right to speak here, not to be interrupted.
(Clare): Do not misrepresent.
Let him misrepresent; it is all to the good.
I think this attempt that is being repeated here to prevent me, by interruptions, from speaking is cowardly. I think I am as much entitled to speak as anybody else.
(Clare): I am not going to allow the Minister or any Deputy in this Dáil to misrepresent me.
I do suggest that these interruptions are an attempt to prevent me from speaking.
(Clare): Who is hedging now?
Order.

I say that these interruptions are intended to prevent me from speaking, and I tell Deputy Hogan, further, that he is not going to put me off the point I am going to make. The Deputy, like Deputy de Valera, whom he copied, made the point that the British in this country in the old days, before we got self-government, whenever they were in difficulties discovered a plot, and he expressly stated, here in the presence of everybody, that that is one technique to-day that we are copying them in, that we are discovering a plot which does not exist. Now, what is the plot? Is there any Deputy in this House who does not know that there is a plot to abolish trial by jury here in certain cases? Is there any Deputy on the benches opposite who will deny, by statement, that there is a deliberate plot being hatched and organised at the present moment to prevent certain criminal cases from coming before the juries of this country? Will Deputy Hogan deny it?
To what extent?
Let me go on. Will Deputy Hogan deny that that plot is there? Will any Deputy on the opposite benches deny it? What further evidence do they want?
But the statement of the Minister.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Boland Mr. G. Boland
Speaker.P: Carry on.
I will carry on.
The Minister should be allowed to speak.
The reason I am being interrupted is because I am telling the truth absolutely.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. B. O'Connor Mr. B. O'Connor
Speaker.P: And because it is very bitter.

Because it is bitter. Will any Deputy on the benches opposite, or on any bench, deny that there is a cowardly plot at the present moment to smash trial by jury in this country? There is no interruption now.
There is silence now.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Boland Mr. G. Boland
Speaker.P: Is that a rhetorical question or does the Minister want an answer right off?
I will have the answer.
If you want silence you can have it. If you do not, you can have interruptions.
Allow the Minister to proceed.
Did not he ask for it?
That is part of his tactics.

Order. Deputies ought to realise that this is a very serious matter, and I suggest that it ought to be treated in a serious way from all sides of the House, and that Deputies ought to be allowed to make their speeches without interruption. I am certainly not going to allow any further interruption from any side of the House. I want to repeat that. Apparently there is at least one member of the House who seems to take it as a joke. I am not going to allow any further interruptions from any side of the House by anybody in the House.

A Chinn Comhairle, you said that this is a serious matter. I regard it as one of the most serious issues that was ever before this House, because I believe I am a democrat and I believe that trial by jury is the most essential but at the same time the most vulnerable institution of democratic government. I ask here now, and I want an answer to that question, an answer in the way that it should come if any Deputy is to follow me. Does any Deputy in this House deny that there is a cowardly and well organised attempt to smash trial by jury in this country at the present moment? I would like an answer to that question and if any Deputy in this House is inclined to answer no to that question, I ask him another. What further evidence does he want? Already one juryman has been badly wounded, already an attempt has been made to murder one juryman, specifically because he gave a verdict and because he did not perjure himself; already a witness in another case has been murdered because he told the truth. Do you want any further evidence or is this talk all humbug? If you want any further evidence I will give it to you here and now. I will go a bit further to say, with full responsibility for what I am saying, that I here and now will establish a connection between the party on the benches opposite and the organisation to which belong the members who are doing this. It is not unknown to the House that there are Republican Organisations outside. There is an organisation called the Fianna. There is an organisation that calls itself Comlucht na Pobhlachta and it is not unknown to the House that there is an official organ called “An Phoblacht.” I will read an extract from it, dated February 23rd, 1929.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S.T. O'Kelly Mr. S.T. O'Kelly
Speaker.P: May I interrupt the Minister. When he is quoting the name of an organisation he might quote it correctly. I know he does not know Irish.

I know none, and I know very nearly as much as the Deputy, from what I understand from people who do know it. That is an entirely irrelevant interruption, and this debate is a little too serious for that. That organ of the Republicans, “An Phoblacht,” on February 23rd, stated:—

“In Maryborough Jail Hogan and Con Healy have been treated as ordinary convicts. The slave-minded jurors who convicted them are responsible, and are paying for their treachery. One is lying in a Dublin hospital, the others having to be protected by England's secret service men.”

MainHeading.P: There is another statement:—

“Denial of a Rumour.—We have heard that a brother of Mr. White, Nevada, Terenure, is spreading a rumour around town to the effect that Mr. John White was not on the jury that convicted Con Healy and sent him to penal servitude for five years. This is not a fact. All good Republicans will be delighted to know that this is not a fact. He was on that jury. Well he knows it.”

That is the organ of the Republicans. That is the organ of the so-called gunmen. I have another paper here. It is not the organ of the Republicans. It is the organ of the Fianna Fáil Party — Republican Party in brackets.

Speaker.P: The Fianna Fáil Party has no organ.

May I be allowed to continue? You will not get away with that now, Deputy O'Kelly. This is a paper called “The Nation.” The editor of this paper is the Deputy who sits opposite there. So far as that Party over there have any organ, this is their organ, and it is the merest quibble to say this is not their organ, and whilst the Deputies opposite are capable of denying a lot, they are not deny before the public that that is their organ. I know they have reason to be ashamed of it.
I will deny it for them. The Fianna Fáil Party have no organ, official or semi-official.
This is the organ of— I forget the Deputy's official title; he used to be Vice-President of the Republic, but he is now Vice-President——
The Deputy is Deputy O'Kelly in this House.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Boland Mr. G. Boland
Speaker.P: When we came into the House, as a matter of procedure, I understood the President to say that we were to accept definite statements made by them as true, and that they, on their side, would take definite statements made by the members of this Party as true also. Deputy O'Kelly has made a definite statement, and the Minister has completely turned it down. I should like to know is that consistent with what we understood was to be the arrangement between the two Parties?

Deputy O'Kelly is trying to get away with the point that this is not the organ of the Party. All right, I accept that—we are glad to know that at least. This is the paper edited by the Deputy opposite—the Vice-Chairman of the Party. Members of the Party contribute to it every week.
They do not—I wish they did.

It expressed their point of view through the country, and the pettifogging distinction which the Deputy makes in order to save his face is one of the meanest distinctions that I ever listened to. Take this article in the paper—it is signed “M.G. MacB.”
Will the Minister give the date?
“The Nation” of February 23rd, 1929. The person who writes these articles for “An Phoblacht” is the same person. I shall read it:

MainHeading.P: “As the ‘Prisoners' Notes’ are often too gloomy, I am going to improve them this week by a few cheering items. If anyone wants an amusing sight let him venture out on a cold, wet day and view sad and shady-looking C.I.D. men standing outside the houses and also the business premises where the jurymen live or are employed, who were cowardly and misguided enough to convict of treason that Tipperary Volunteer, Con Healy, who has devoted his whole life to unselfish service of the nation, and thus handed him over to British vengeance—five years in Maryborough hell. The employers of some of these jurymen are not at all flattered by the assiduities of the C.I.D. They have to do business in the Irish nation, and it is never a good business advertisement to be watched by the police; people seem to take malicious pleasure in asking them why their premises are being watched.”

This appears on the very same date as the notes in “An Phoblacht,” after there was an attempt to murder a juryman. For what? Because he did not perjure himself—a fashion able crime in this country. Where does it appear? It appears in an organ edited by the Deputy who sits opposite, and to which Deputies on the opposite benches make weekly contributions; it appears in an organ that puts the point of view of the Fianna Fáil Party to the country. Who writes it? The very same person who writes the incitements to murder in “An Phoblacht.” Then take “The Nation” of April 6th, 1929:—“Fianna Eireann (Boy Scouts of Ireland)”—we all know them well. This appeared after the last election in Dublin at which Deputy O'Higgins referred to the men who attempted to murder Mr. White and who murdered the witness as “sewer rats”—a perfectly proper term, in my opinion. He referred specifically to them and here is the comment signed “Langlaoich, Chief Scout”:—

Speaker.P: Another Irishman.
Another gentleman who signs himself “Director of Organisation.” Here is what he writes:—
“Yesterday England's John French called us vipers. To-day England's Free State spokesmen call us sewer rats.”

MainHeading.P: The men who attempted that murder were called sewer rats by Deputy O'Higgins and they come out with this note in the “Nation.” What is that? Is that a condonation of this murder? Is that a justification in Deputy O'Kelly's paper of this murder? If it is not, what is it, and what is the explanation of it? If Deputy Hogan wants any further evidence of conspiracy, will he be good enough to indicate what sort of further evidence he requires? The Deputy knows it well.
The very night Mr. Armstrong was murdered Deputy Cooney makes this statement in the Dáil:—
“Will the Minister deny, on the other hand, that we have in this State an Executive Council imprisoning men who tear down the Union Jack, which is not the flag of this country?”

I have here sheaves of these documents issued by this organisation with which Deputy O'Kelly and the organ which he edits, and to which Deputies opposite contribute, are so closely allied. Here are some of the contents of these documents:—

“To Irish Citizens. Break the connection with the British Empire. The Irish Republican Army are striving to-day as Tone strove in another generation to free Ireland from British rule. Unfortunately some of Dublin's degenerate and slavish citizens assist them in their work. Last month the following” (then follows a list of jurors, headed by “John White, ‘Nevada,’ 3 Ashdale Road, Terenure)....”

Every one of the Deputies opposite knows of these, and the cowardly pretence that they do not know that there is an organisation attempting to murder jurors and to break down the law at present is beneath contempt. Every Deputy knows of all these publications—knows that these organisations are there and issuing these publications. Here is another, issued the next week, after the job had been done:—
“Packed Juries: John White, ‘Nevada,” 23 Ashdale Road, Terenure (now in Steevens' Hospital)....”
Deputy Hogan cannot speak again in this debate, but I hope he is satisfied that there is a conspiracy. If he likes, I shall continue to read further extracts.

Speaker.P: (Clare): Please yourself.
On this particular point, I want to know where does Fianna Fáil stand. It is true that under pressure certain statements were made disapproving of these murders.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Boland Mr. G. Boland
Speaker.P: Under no pressure whatever.

What is the explanation of this? Why is it that “The Nation” publishes practically the same incitements to and condonation of murder and of this campaign as the organ of the people who are doing this? I was a little amused listening to Deputy Derrig saying that we were afraid of the Cumann na mBan —when he was trying to make a joke of this issue and suggesting that all that was behind this Bill was that some member of the organisation known as the Cumann na mBan might shake her fist at the Minister for Justice. He was indulging in utterly cheap and trifling jeers which are absolutely out of place on a subject like this, and asking what was the reason for this. I want an answer to another question. I want to know where Fianna Fáil stands in this matter. I want to know why it is necessary for their organ—it may not be their official organ—to condone this; why it was necessary for Deputy de Valera yesterday practically to condone it, as I will prove out of his own mouth.

MainHeading.P: I shall tell Deputies opposite, I told them before. They need not worry too much about us. We will not lie awake at night over these matters; we tackled bigger problems than these and solved them and we shall take whatever steps are necessary to save the jury system and jurors in Dublin. Democracy must protect itself as well as any other form of Government and we would be unworthy of the great men who went before us, and sat on these benches, if we did not take what steps were necessary to protect the right of the citizens to be tried before a judge and jury under an equal law in this country and we will do it, and if necessary abrogate that right for a period. Deputy Hogan can hear that. We are not afraid of the Cumann na mBan, or the little gang who are carrying out this campaign. I shall tell the House the position of Deputies opposite. It is exactly as I said it was on the Annuities debate. Any gang of ruffians in this country who shout the word “Republic” louder than you are your masters. You will learn that yet, absolutely. The day you challenged the Government that had the authority of the Irish people behind it, the day the leader of the party opposite brought about the civil war in this country, and talked about wading through blood, that day he put himself into the position that he is, that he will be, and will always continue to be in, that is at the mercy of any gang of ruffians, no matter how illiterate, how criminal, who care to shout the word “Republic” louder than he does. I say deliberately that the attitude of the party opposite on this Bill can be explained on no other basis except that they are afraid of these men and that they must be their spokesmen and must try to make it impossible for us to deal with them. But we will deal with them. I would not make so little of myself as to answer the arguments put forward by the opposite side.

Deputy Tierney explained that there was a difference between this Government elected by the people in 1922 and Mr. Balfour. Deputies opposite know that. Of course, they know it, but they have to keep up the pretence. They have landed themselves in this particular mess. Deputy Tierney also explained that trial by jury was being attacked. Deputies opposite know that. Deputy Tierney went to great trouble to explain that if the Party opposite ever got a majority, which they never will, in my opinion, they could abolish the Oath. Deputies know that; it is sheer waste of time to repeat these arguments to them; they know every bit of them. You have to use other arguments altogether.

To get back to Deputy de Valera. He declared: “The Minister for Justice had indicated his whole position and the attitude of the Government in the last part of his speech. He threatened them with another twist of the screw. Listening to the Minister he (Mr. de Valera) felt that he was reading some of the speeches made by Forster, Balfour, and, in later times, by Sir Hamar Greenwood. The whole attitude of the Ministry, and particularly the Ministry of Justice, in recent times had been one that proved the thesis maintained by Dr. MacNeill in the old ‘Volunteer’ days of the continuity of British Government in this country. The Minister for Justice told them the Bill was an improvement of the law. But instead it went behind Magna Charta and undid every liberty for which men had been fighting and which they had won.”

Coming from the mouth of a man who told the people some years ago that they had no right to do wrong; who told them the issue between majority and minority rule might well have to be bloodily fought out —I well remember the cliché—coming from this man it is the most arrant piece of hypocrisy I ever heard of. He went on to say that the Minister knew perfectly well that this was the kind of a Bill that would receive no sort of support from the Fianna Fáil Party in this House, and further he said: “They knew that crimes were committed, but no one on the Fianna Fáil Benches had attempted to condone these crimes. Was it because those two crimes had been committed that the people were to be deprived of trial by jury—the only safeguard that a citizen had?” Deputies should make no mistake. We are not concerned with protecting the criminal. The point of this Bill is not to protect the criminal, but to protect the jurors. We are thinking of the citizens, we are not thinking of the few criminals in the country, but of the people in the country. With regard to the charge of packing juries, we never pack juries. “Was it because one juror was wounded and a witness killed?”

He quoted the speech made by Mr. Balfour at great length and asked the House to reject this Bill “because there was a way of dealing with the situation—a way which would be successful where coercion would fail, and that was by giving all the people of the country an opportunity of accepting an Irish Assembly for the making of laws. ...I say a man has a fundamental duty not to be the instrument of corrupt and tyrannical power.” You can divide these statements into two classes. There is one class which points out that we are exactly in the same position as Balfour and Forster—members of a Government who had no right whatever in this country and who were endeavouring to oppress the country and had no authority from the people. He tells us, further, that there is a way to settle this question—that there will be no necessity for this Bill if we scrap the Treaty. I do not hesitate to say that that is an absolute condonation of what has gone on. If we are in the position of Forster, we deserve to be shot and we will not whine about it. If we are in the position of Forster or Balfour, then the Irish people should deal with us. If we have no authority here, we are traitors in this country and the men who are our agents, if you wish, the men who are carrying out the law, judges and jurors, deserve the fate they are getting. That is the clear implication. If that is not the implication, what is it? Of course, again it is the old story—make a statement sufficiently vague that it can be read by one side in one sense and by another in another. That brings me back to the “wading through blood” speech made at a most critical time, 1922.

Deputy de Valera spoke about continuity with the British Government. There is continuity there—it is the same old story—the man who is always willing to speak daggers but uses none. I have positively more respect for the men who are committing murder than the men who are giving them authority for doing it because that is giving them authority for doing it. The Bill may be effective or ineffective but it will be tried and we will take whatever steps are necessary. Until the majority of the Dáil turn us out we have a sacred responsibility, and we would be nothing better than arrant poltroons if we did not stand up to that responsibility. Whatever steps may be necessary to deal with this campaign, we shall take. We have tackled bigger problems. I read with some amusement. Deputy Lemass advising us, as an alternative, to sack the heads of the police force. He spoke of their inefficiency. He is a good judge of inefficiency— I will say that. It came rather well from the Deputy who is the spokesman of members of this organisation and who has been squealing in the Dáil for the last six months because of the activities of the C.I.D. Make no mistake about it. We have had a pretty troubled time for the last five or six years. Deputy Hogan will be glad to know that we have made some attempt to establish decent democratic conditions in this country. We have made an attempt to show the British Government that they were wrong—that it was possible to give every man and woman an equal voice in the running of this country and at the same time establish a decent liberal country with decent liberal, social ideas. We have done that. Our reputation is fairly high in that respect all over the world. We are not going to smirch it now; we are not going to allow any gang of misguided criminals or any persons who may be their patrons to wreck the State, and we are prepared to take any steps necessary to deal with this menace. I am glad to say that the menace is not nearly as big a problem, is not nearly as dangerous as many of the problems that we met and solved.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. Boland Mr. G. Boland
Speaker.P: The Minister for Agriculture has said that he would not make so little of himself as to answer the arguments of the Opposition Party. He fell back on his old weapon of vituperation. He asked the a definite question. He asked the people on this side are they afraid to deny, or will they deny, that there is a conspiracy to break up the jury system. I am prepared to admit that there is evidence of a conspiracy to do that. But the Minister himself says that this is only a gang of misguided criminals who are attempting this, and under cover of this vituperation and the panic of the Front Bench the Government are going to do something to amend the whole criminal law of the country. If this gang of misguided criminals that the Minister knows so much about are trying to break up the jury system, what excuse is that for the Minister making a farce of the whole system of trial by jury? Can he not be straight about it and bring into effect some of those emergency measures that they have on their Statute Book? The Minister said definitely that he was going to establish a connection between the Fianna Fáil Party and the murder gang. He failed miserably in that attempt. He quoted a letter from the “Nation” newspaper, edited by Deputy Seán T. O'Kelly——
Not a letter, an article.
A signed letter. I understood the Minister gave the initials of the signature.
The article was signed. Another article was unsigned.

It was signed by the writer. Anyway, that is not our affair. It is not the affair of the Fianna Fáil Party. What appears in the “Nation” is not the affair of Fianna Fáil. It is the affair, I presume, of the editor. It is also not true to say that every member of this Party subscribes to that paper.
I did not say that.

He did not. Let that be taken in any way the Minister likes. The Minister has not established any connection between this Party and the murder gang, and neither is anyone here afraid to denounce crime wherever he finds it. What are we asked to do in this Bill? We are asked to give into the hands of that Government the semblance of trying people by jury, when as a matter of fact it will be drumhead courtmartial that we will have established. We will have established a perambulating jury; a jury of unknown people can be brought round the country under the provisions of this Bill. Who is to know but that these people may be members of the C.I.D.? They may be people who have been found to have returned a satisfactory verdict in other cases and who can be relied on to do the same in the future. They can be brought into areas where convictions are required—to do the work that the Executive Council wants them to do. These gentlemen who want to secure that power for themselves are notorious for their contempt of the law. Starting with the Minister who has just sat down who could not wait for an accused man twelve or eighteen months ago to get an ordinary trial, but had to get up and accuse him of a crime before he had been tried——
On a point of order, the less the Deputy says about that case the better for himself.
Perhaps the Deputy is the best judge of that.

The Minister commented on a case that was awaiting trial. Speaking in this House on another occasion, on 28th March, 1928, the Minister for Industry and Commerce said that two other prisoners who were awaiting trial were guilty although they had not been tried. Is that not contempt of law and the court which every plain and honest citizen at least knows something about? The President, the first citizen of the State as he ought to be——
He is.
Say it louder. He ought to be anyway.
He is.

The President, on 17th November, 1926, when speaking on another of these panic Bills, the Emergency Powers Bill, referred to a, prisoner awaiting trial, a man who had been arrested in the Midlands. He did not exactly give his name, but everything else. He indicated beyond yea or nay who the man was and left no doubt in anyone's mind as to the guilt of this man, before that man met his trial. If that is the respect for the ordinary, decent law which every plain citizen knows should be observed when a man is on trial for his life or liberty, then I make him a present of their respect for the law.

I pass over the Minister's statement that this was the most disgraceful debate he ever listened to, because I heard him say the same on practically every debate here. He said the same on the Unemployment Debate, when Deputies from every Party, including his own Party, gave a picture of the state of destitution to which their constituents were reduced. On that occasion the Minister for Agriculture got up and said he was ashamed of them for showing their sores in public. In fact, in every debate of any sort in this House the Minister has adopted the same attitude. It is a pity anyone else is allowed to talk at all except the Minister himself.

We had to-day an example of acting in haste and repenting at leisure as the first business of the day. At the time I withdrew the implication or the suggestion that I made I said that the President had got a cut-and-dried scheme, and, of course, he had not, because the thing was too foolish. But he was able to get his solid majority to follow him into the lobby in favour of the most foolish resolution that was ever put before the House when the people of all parties sat down to consider it. We had the spectacle before the whole House of that resolution. What is going to happen to this Bill?

MainHeading.P: We had desperate measures brought in here, and big majorities for them, and then these measures were left in abeyance. We were told that the whole life of the nation and the future of the country were depending upon them, and then nothing was done. As Deputy Hogan very clearly pointed out, there is something serious behind this Bill. If it were an Emergency Bill we might pass it and never use it. But it is another of these stunts. There is another election coming off. The speech in the Rotunda was on the eve of the election in North Dublin. There is another by-election coming off in Sligo-Leitrim, and this is another emergency measure to meet the case of the election in Sligo-Leitrim. It is simply a by-election stunt, but it is more serious.

Deputy Hogan wanted to know what about the ordinary citizens. He belongs to a Party that more or less did not take part in the struggle as we did here. Speaking for the ordinary citizen, are you going to allow vituperative speeches like that of the Minister to carry you off your feet, to carry you away from your better judgment, so that the permanent criminal law of the country may be altered because what the Minister calls a gang of misguided criminals are attempting to break up the jury system? If there is such a situation let them bring in some of their emergency measures to deal with it. The President, when he found how far the words that he would like to have confined to North Dublin travelled, when he found they got to Australia, to America, and to the rest of the world, was very anxious to make clear that the situation was not nearly as bad as his speech would indicate. In fact, things were almost normal.

Speaker.P: It was Ketchem said that.
Yes, that was only Ketchem's interpretation of the speech. I think he was quite justified in gathering such impressions from the Rotunda speech.
He did not know him.

He did not know him as well as we do. I hope Mr. Ketchem will remember the words the President let drop to-day. We are asked to pass this Bill which will give power to a jury of unknown people—they may be C.I.D. or they may be accommodating citizens who will bring in any verdict that is required—to try accused persons. That jury can be brought all round the country.
With their numbers.

Yes, they will be known only by numbers. They will be prepared to bring in any verdict that is required, and they will be put up to hear every class of case, whether it is a murder, an ordinary crime, or anything else. It does not matter whether the case has a political significance. This is going to be the law of the country, and before people allow the Minister for Agriculture, with all his abuse and vituperation, to rush them off their feet, they should consider that aspect.

We had a debate on the question of prisoners in March, 1928, and I made a suggestion there which, if adopted, would have obviated a lot of trouble. I claim to be a lover of peace although on a few occasions I did things that might not have have been too peaceful. However, I made a desperate effort on that occasion to get the Government to exercise a bit of commonsense and wipe the state. I appealed to them to give a chance to the people on the run and to stop the civil war. They turned down that suggestion. For the benefit of the Minister who is present I will read a small passage from the remarks I made in 1928. I believe if my suggestion had been acted upon we would not have had all this trouble. Let me not now be taken as trying to justify the shooting of Mr. White or Mr. Armstrong. I say that if the suggestion I made at that time had been acted on there would have been none of the shooting.

MainHeading.P: On the 21st March, 1928, I spoke about the harsh treatment meted out to one prisoner who came out, being forced out by economic causes. He got nine months for escaping, for walking out of the prison. I went on to say: “The others are going to keep as they are until they are beaten. On the occasion that I refer to, I also suggested to the Minister that the practice of bounding down these men on the run, as well as the incident that occurred a couple of days before in Clonmel, when one of those escaped men was fired on and wounded by the Guard would inevitably, if the Government did not take a decent line in this matter, lead to somebody amongst those prisoners firing back on the Guards. I am forced back to the statement I made in the debate on the Supplementary Estimate when I said that every effort that had been made by this Party here either to forget the past or to get the country into a decent line of ordered government again has been simply turned down, and that one attempt after another has been made to stir up strife again.” The root cause of all this was that there were men hounded down. They were not going to face nine months' imprisonment. Some men are hotter than others and when they were pursued there was always the danger that they would fire back. One of them did and he got five years. If the Government had given them a chance and wiped the slate clean there would be none of this.

Is there such a situation in the country at present that the Government is justified in bringing in this measure to alter permanently the fundamental criminal law? If there is, then the President's contradictions of reports in the American Press and of Mr. Ketchem's articles are wrong. President Cosgrave said that things are practically normal. He said there was a small gang. Surely he will not hold that a small gang of people, who are probably known, is going to be the excuse for altering the criminal law so as to remove all public confidence in fair trial. That point is especially important because this is a Government elected by the Irish people. This Government have, on my own showing, been guilty of contempt of court because Ministers stated in this House that people who were not tried but who were in custody were guilty. We are told when we say that a person should be considered innocent until proved guilty that we are using a cliché of British Liberalism. I do not care what it is; I maintain it is a sound principle and it is a protection for the ordinary citizen. A man should be considered innocent until he is proved guilty. We are told that is a cliché of British origin. The whole thing reminds me of the man who got a steam-hammer to break a nut.

The Minister states that they have been examining closely the working of the jury system; that they were going to improve the jury system by this Bill which makes it possible for one jury to try all the cases they want to try. The Minister said they were obliged to alter things to meet present day requirements. That is a very significant statement to make. Deputy Flinn suggests that Sligo-Leitrim is the excuse and I think that is about the size of it. Other methods, we are told, will be used. I suggest that if the situation is so serious those other methods should be used. There are all sorts of threats by Government speakers. If the situation is as bad as they say, let them try those other methods and leave the jury system alone. Some Deputy—I think it was Deputy Hogan—said, quite truly too, that even with the case of a juryman being killed, or a sheriff, the present law would be able to deal with the people who did it.

Deputy Tierney made a statement with which I entirely agree. He admitted that this organisation would die if violence were not used against it. I claim that violence has been used by the Government to keep that organisation in existence. I said last March twelve months that the very action you were taking was keeping this organisation in existence. I agree with Deputy Tierney although he meant it the other way.

It comes to the same thing. We came to the same conclusion from different sides and we met in the centre. Violence begets violence. They have made no attempt to treat the thing in a decent, straightforward, and manly way. They are going on with this vituperation, pin-pricking, and steam-hammering. They came in to-day with another emergency measure to deal with disorder but they asked the House to discharge the order in that case. I think they would have more respect from this Party and from the rest of the country if they treated the thing in a decent and manly way.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. O'Sullivan Mr. G. O'Sullivan
Speaker.P: I speak on this measure from a rather narrow angle. I represent County Dublin which supplies jurors, one of whom was “only wounded.” Deputy MacEntee appears to sneer, but I would ask him to reply to questions which I shall put up. I am speaking for the people of County Dublin who sent me here, and they are the persons for whom this Bill is drafted. It is a Bill entitled an Act to make further and better provision for the protection of jurors and others concerned. That is the first reason why I speak. The second reason is because it was suggested here last evening that I never make a speech in this House because I am afraid. Whoever said that probably does not know me. The third reason why I speak is that I promise not to go back beyond the Act of Union. I happen to have the Official Reports here, and there is one quotation which I will make from them. After Deputy Boland's statement about terrorism, pin-pricks, sledge hammers and everything else, I would ask the House to listen to this quotation. Some Deputies will, no doubt, recall it, and those who cannot will hear it. On the 20th December, 1921, a Deputy speaking in Dáil Eireann asked: “Who would sit in judgement on the Irish people?” President de Valera replied: “Themselves.”

MainHeading.P: Now that is the principle which this Bill insists upon, namely, that the Irish people have the right to sit in judgement upon themselves. I am quoting the words of the Leader of the Official Opposition himself and I want him and the House to understand that his statement last evening, when he went beyond the Act of Union and quoted speeches made in the British House of Commons, was answered by himself on the 20th December, 1921, when he said that the Irish people are the only and competent judges as to what is and what is not right in this country. If the people desire to change what is called the criminal law in this country they have a right to do it whether it is for good or evil. I believe that any measure which this House would pass to protect the jurors of the country, especially those of the County of Dublin, in whom Deputy MacEntee and myself are so interested, would have the whole-hearted support of the people of this country. It is very easy to get up in this House and say that So-and-so said that twenty years ago, that Balfour said that thirty years ago, or that somebody else said something else over a hundred years ago. It is easy to read out a series of Acts of repression which were passed by the British Houses of Parliament which purported to make laws for this country. It is an insult to this House to suggest that the laws which are enacted here are to be put on a parallel with those enacted in the British House of Commons, ten, twenty, or fifty years ago. The regrettable situation is that the chief Opposition in this House will not take upon itself the responsibility of condemning these crimes. I heard Deputy Tierney say that Deputy de Valera said that there was only one man wounded. If I remember rightly, and I am prepared to be corrected, Deputy de Valera said that if there were ten or fifteen wounded was it not better than that something else should happen?

Speaker.P: I was not here at the time. The important thing is the something else. I do not know what that is.

I do not know either—that is the catch—probably better that something else should happen than that one innocent man should be convicted. At least, that, I think, is what he meant. Is it not better that one, ten, or fifteen jurors should be only wounded than that one innocent man should be convicted? That is not the principle at stake in this Bill at all. I hope that no innocent man will be found guilty. I regret to think that the ordinary criminal law, as they call it, is being paraded here, and it is suggested that Deputies on the other side of the House stand up for the ordinary criminal law. It is great for them to do so to-day, and to think that now all we want is the ordinary criminal law. Occasions were when it did not please them. There is no doubt that the Minister for Agriculture is right when he says that the members on the benches opposite must take their full responsibility for the happenings in this country They must take responsibility for what may happen as the result of statements made in this House last evening.

MainHeading.P: The Executive Council were described, not individually, but so far as I remember, as the Balfours and Forsters. I know that Deputy de Valera will come in and say: “I never said that.” What did he mean when he talked about Sergeant Sheridans? That is the ordinary criminal law which they want to stand over to-day. They say that it is being filched from them. They say that they want the Sergeant Sheridans and that they want the laws administered to them by the Forsters. Deputy de Valera recalled even the Maam Cross murders and talked of the tyranny of the law. He declaimed that he was the one Deputy in the House who loved fair play. He appealed to the consciences of members on this side of the House. I wonder does the Deputy realise that there are other people besides himself who have consciences. Will the Deputy's conscience awaken to a sense of responsibility in regard to the speech he made last night, and to other speeches, if another juror is only wounded, or if another witness is only murdered? Will he then come back to the House and say: “You misinterpreted me,” as he said in a famous speech that there were still in this county young men who might have to wade through the blood of Irish soldiers or Irish Ministers? He will come back and say: “That is not what I meant, but that is what people will say I meant.” He is the person who has said it. It all comes back to the question of respect for this House as the law-making authority in this country.

Deputy de Valera and his Party must accept that or not accept it. If he gets up in this House and says he does not accept it let the country decide. If the country is not satisfied with what Deputy Boland and Deputy Lemass are so pleased with, the common criminal law, they can alter it. They have the right to do wrong. On the 20th December, 1921, the Leader of His Majesty's Opposition in this House accepted that. “Who will sit in judgment on the Irish people?—President de Valera; Themselves.” The Irish people have sat in judgment and have decided this matter.

Speaker.P: What was the decision?
Who is the authority to make laws or decide what the law is?
The Farmers' Party.
Do not worry about the Farmers' Party.
We are not worrying about them. They will not trouble us after the next election.
You will not be here to worry about them anyhow.

I must claim the right if we are to have these little asides to quote the chief election poster posted up in County Dublin. “Peace with England, never—Vote 1 MacEntee.” The people of County Dublin, the jurors whom we ask the House to protect, because jurors are principally drawn from the County and City of Dublin, these are the persons——
Who elected Deputy MacEntee? He is here.
He was only an “also ran.”
He was elected before you. He is here.

I am talking of the respect for this House and the authority for it, the people's voice. I am sorry I misquoted the poster I read just now. It said: “Vote I Brennan.” That was posted outside the Asylum in Dundrum.
And inside appealing to the appropriate electorate for their votes was the poster “Vote I O'Sullivan.”
But all your followers got out of there.
Yours are kept in.
The Deputy must address the Chair.

This is a quotation from another poster: “Jurors, who prove their loyalty to the British Empire by convicting Irish Republican political prisoners, to be given a free passage for self and family to any desired part of the Empire—(Better protection guaranteed than that given to the unfortunate Carey).” While Deputies on the opposite benches have not condemned these things they have used every opportunity of attacking the institutions which this House and the country have set up in this State to preserve order, whether it is the Gárda Síochána, the Courts of Justice, or the prisons they detest so much. They have used every opportunity of freedom which the House gives them to attack these institutions. If, as I have said, in two or three months, another juror or ten or fifteen jurors, as Deputy de Valera said, are “only wounded” and other witnesses are “only murdered,” I hope he will come back to the House and say, “Yes, these are the words I did use on that occasion.” Deputy Boland spoke at some length in an attack on the administration of justice. There is a way of dealing with that. This Bill intends to protect jurors and witnesses concerned in the criminal trials and proposes for that purpose to amend the Juries Act.

MainHeading.P: I would suggest that there is no reason why solicitors and counsel should be excluded from the courts. I am sure the Minister knows that they are persons who would not avail of any information they would receive in court to do anything which would be derogatory to the strict administration of justice. I think it is very important that every step should be taken to protect jurors, even that of numbering them. As I said in opening, a very large number of them come from County Dublin, which I represent. I think every step should be taken to make it more difficult for persons who desire to kill them and to make it more difficult for persons of the type of Deputy de Valera and his followers to get up here when an unfortunate man has been killed or wounded and say “that is what he deserved.” I desire to support the Bill as representing a class from whom the jurors of the country are chiefly drawn.

Speaker.P: It was agreed that item No. 1 should be taken at seven o'clock. It is now four minutes to seven, and I think it would be better to take it now rather than to interrupt the next Deputy's speech.
I formally move the adjournment of the debate.
Debate accordingly adjourned.

MainHeading.Title: Private Business. - Superannuations and Pensions Bill, 1929—From the Seanad.
MainHeading.P: The Dáil went into Committee to consider the following recommendations from the Seanad:—
1. Section 3 (1). That all after the word “payable,” line 16, be deleted down to the end of the sub-section.
2. Section 3 (2). That all after the word “of,” line 22, be deleted down to the end of the sub-section and that the words “both Houses” be substituted therefor.

Speaker.P: I said to-day that I was prepared to accept recommendation No. 1. It alters the complexion of the Order which may be made by the Minister. As the amendment left the House the Order would contain a penalty or penalties, and the penalties are now removed, if this recommendation be accepted. I move the acceptance of the recommendation.
I agree with the recommendation. As far as I can see, it is only reasonable.
Question—“That the Committee agree with the Seanad in the said recommendation”—put and agreed to.

I am disposed to ask the Committee to reject recommendation No. 2. It is a recommendation which associates the Seanad in the matter of finance. As I said to-day, I was not disposed to agree to this recommendation. The control of finance should be within the power of the Dáil. I therefore move the rejection of the recommendation.
Question—“That the Committee do not agree with the Seanad in recommendation No. 2”—put and agreed to.
The Dáil went out of Committee.
Agreement with recommendation No. 1 and rejection of recommendation No. 2 reported.
Ordered: That the Seanad be informed accordingly.

MainHeading.Title: Private Business. - Juries (Protection) Bill, 1929—Second Stage (Resumed).

Speaker.P: The Minister for Agriculture told us that he is going to prove the connection between this Party and the murder gang. He proceeded to give us quotations from papers and from articles written by people in the “Nation.”
resumed the Chair.

But the Minister failed hopelessly to do what he set out to do: that is, to prove a connection between this Party and the people responsible for the shootings. I propose to show a connection between some of the Ministers opposite and the gunmen of the present day, as they are called. I think, if I can prove first of all, that a certain Minister at present in the Government urged by every means in his power that all the men of this country should arm themselves, and, secondly, if he deliberately encouraged them to shoot to kill, and thirdly if he deliberately encouraged them to get away with the killing by dumping their arms, then I will have proved my case. I think I can prove the first point by giving the House a quotation from “Irish Freedom,” of December, 1913.
That is a long time ago.

Not quite so long ago as some of the quotations given by Deputy O'Sullivan and others. The Minister for Finance, writing an article on “Arms and Drill,” told the young men of the country: “There is no power in politics like the armed man. He is the final arbiter. When the poets have sung and the orators declaimed, when the politicians have planned and the kings taken counsel, the man with the bayonet shall make law.”
It was worth hearing that, but what is its relevancy?

I do not think, sir, you were in the Chair when the Minister for Agriculture was speaking, but he developed his argument on those lines and challenged us to answer certain arguments that he put forward. Then, as he usually does, evidently thinking so much of his own speech, having made it, he departed and I, sir, with your permission, would like to follow on his arguments.
But how is this an answer to the Minister? I did not hear the Minister, of course, but how is this an answer to whatever he did say?
The Minister set out to prove that there was a connection between this Party and the people who were shooting.
At the moment?
Yes, and he proceeded to give quotations from various papers.
Current papers, I take it?

Current papers. I want to prove that if there are armed men in the country there is one man in this House more responsible than any other, and if you permit me to read the quotations I think I can prove that there is one man responsible more than any man in this House for the armed men in the country at the present day.
I am afraid I could not rule that as relevant. Is not the position this, that the Deputy wants to take us back to the organisation of the Irish National Volunteers?
No. I want to take you back to the men who are in the country at the present day.

That would not be taking me back: that would be keeping me just where I want to be, that is, in the present day I think that the Deputy cannot go into the history of the Irish Volunteers for the purpose of proving who organised them, and what the resulting responsibility was. That is a subject of very great magnitude that is not relevant to this Bill.
Is the Deputy entitled to prove that some members of the Executive Council may be responsible for the situation which exists in the country to-day?
I think not —absolutely not. The vista of debate that opens out is vast and limitless.

We have before us at the present time a Bill to punish the armed men. Would it not be far more just for us to get at the man who is responsible for the armed men? I want to fix the blame definitely on the present Minister for Finance, and I think I can do so if you give me permission to read the quotations that I have.
The Deputy must bring us nearer home than 1913, and take periodicals of more recent date than “Irish Freedom.”
I am sorry that other speakers got a certain amount of liberty while you, sir, were out of the Chair. Perhaps I was unfortunate in this, that I stood up at the moment that you came back.

I do not accept for a moment the view of the Deputy that more latitude is given when I am out of the Chair than when I am in it. I have heard the reverse view also put very strongly. The Deputy will get every liberty possible if he confines himself to the subject of this Bill. But I think he will himself realise that although I did allow him to quote one excellent piece of English——
That was only the first one.

I know it was not all. I allowed the Deputy to quote one, but I think he will realise that the area of quotations is very large and the number of persons it would be possible to quote very great. That could not be done. It would carry us far away from this Bill—absolutely away from it.

The whole point that I had to make was that we were accused of being connected in some mysterious way or another with these armed men. The Minister for Agriculture deliberately made that statement. He made it in a very eloquent fashion, and having set out to prove it, he merely gave a few quotations from some papers and then proved nothing. My whole case is, that if there are armed men in the country those armed men were brought into existence by certain articles that were written previously, and that there is a continuity between those articles and the armed men that we have in the country at the present day. However, if I am not allowed to give the quotations perhaps I will be allowed to prove the three points that I set out to prove.

The Deputy will have to prove some connection between the individuals and the people at the moment. As I understand the Deputy's rendering of the Minister's speech, it is to prove a connection between another Party and the present criminals in arms.
It is the latter that I am trying to prove: a connection between his Party and the present armed men.
A present-day connection must be proved. Is the Deputy not continuing?
No, it knocks the whole argument. If I am not allowed to rebut the Minister in that way there is nothing for me only to sit down.

I hope I will not attempt anything so nonsensical as to connect somebody who had something to do with the starting of the Volunteers sixteen years ago with the armed men of to-day. I had not the pleasure of listening to the Minister for Agriculture, and I do not know what attempt he made to connect the chief Opposition Party with the armed men of to-day. I feel certain that if he did try to make a connection that it had relation to to-day and not to sixteen years ago. I think it is entirely beside the point to make a case against the men who were in the organisation of Volunteers. The opponents of the measure here, as Deputy O'Higgins said last night, try to make a case for the man on trial, be he guilty or innocent. We would all like to make that case, but there is a man entitled to consideration before the person on trial, and that is the man who is called in from his business or ordinary calling to serve on a jury for the trial of a case. We have not heard from the chief Opposition members any genuine expression of regret, at least as far as I have heard, of the treatment of jurymen in Dublin. No suggestion has been made by that Opposition Party that would offer security to those people. When a man is taken from his ordinary calling and brought into court to deliver a verdict, he is bound by his oath, and he calls upon his Creator to witness the truth of his verdict. I believe the Government that calls on a man to perform that duty has an obligation towards him to see that he is protected and that he will not suffer for any verdict he brings in.

Deputy de Valera said yesterday that the existing law was sufficient for his protection. I wonder has Deputy de Valera been living in the moon, or has he been living in Dublin city, or has he been viewing those things through smoked glasses which give whatever hue he wants? Not only did Deputy de Valera say that, but to the ordinary man listening to his speech there ran through it an undercurrent, if I may say so, of approval of the treatment jurors were receiving. Has the ordinary law given sufficient protection to jurors? One juryman was shot at and wounded and a man who gave evidence was murdered. Of what use was the ordinary law to these people, and is it because they were only jurymen that they should not get protection? If these people happened to be prominent politicians they would probably get the sympathy of Deputy de Valera, but is it because they are ordinary citizens called in from their every day work to do this duty that they are not entitled to protection? Refusal to provide protection is to my mind a condonation of the crime of shooting down these people. I cannot see anything else to it. If the Government of the day does not give these people protection, if the members of this House will not give them protection, then refusal to do so is nothing less than a condonation of the crime of shooting these jurymen.

MainHeading.P: I am afraid it could be read into Deputy de Valera's speech that not alone was the existing law good enough for the protection of these people, but that the treatment they were getting was also good enough for them. I am not prepared to support the Bill before the House as a permanent measure, and I will not do it. I am prepared, as Deputy Anthony said he was last night, to support any measure which will give protection to the jurymen, even to the extent of the abandonment of the jury system altogether for a time, but I am not prepared to support a measure that will hand down to posterity an Act which is nothing more or less than a prostitution of the jury system. I cannot imagine the application of this Act under normal, peaceful conditions in the country, and I would like to hear from the Minister for Justice if he is satisfied that in normal times this Juries Act would give satisfaction. Personally, I cannot see how in normal peace times there would be any commonsense in calling it a jury system, where the accused person was tried by unknown people. I have very little faith in the Bill. I am afraid it will not achieve its object, but the Government is obliged to protect the jurymen. It is obliged to put down crime, and if the Government thinks that this Bill is sufficient to meet the needs of the day, very well, I am prepared to support it as an emergency measure, but not otherwise.

Speaker.P: The Deputy used the phrase “prostitution of the jury system.” Yet he says he is prepared to support the Bill.
As a temporary measure. If the Government say that this is our best effort to protect the jurymen, then, as an emergency measure, I am prepared to support it.
Temporary prostitution.

Yes, if it fills the bill. Deputy Anthony last evening gave us to understand he was going to vote against the Second Reading of the Bill, but that he would attempt to amend it on Committee. What guarantee has Deputy Anthony that it will ever reach Committee? Personally, I have none. I think it would be better if Deputy Anthony and other people who feel as he does would appeal to the Minister to have this as an emergency measure, and an emergency measure only, so that we can give it the support the Government thinks it ought to get and which one would like to give it for the sake of the people whom it seeks to protect.

I think we have listened to a very interesting speech, and a very interesting revelation of a Deputy's mentality when he, a man apparently who is considered fitted by a certain section of citizens in the country to represent them, is prepared, temporarily even, to support a measure which he himself describes as a prostitution of the jury system. I am not going to repeat the phrase. I think the fact that it has been said once in this House ought to suffice for this Bill. It ought also to suffice for the constituents of any Deputy who is going to support such a measure as this, even temporarily. But it is not going to be a temporary measure: according to the Minister who introduced it, it is not going to be “a mere temporary expedient, but a permanent measure.” Those are the Minister's own words—“not a mere temporary expedient, but a permanent measure,” and I would ask the Deputy, who, I presume, will go into the Division Lobby to support this as a temporary measure, to go into that Lobby realising that it is not, in the words of the Minister, “a mere temporary expedient, but a permanent measure.”
I will take my own responsibility.

That is the Minister's contribution to the liberty of the subject under a Constitution which we have been told is a free Constitution. I would like the Deputy to understand also that this measure does not apply only to those to whom Deputy Tierney, I think, referred as “extraordinary criminals.” It applies to every single citizen of this State who may be charged, rightly or wrongly, with an offence against the laws of this State. It does not apply only to those who may be thought to be responsible for the recent attacks upon jurors; it applies to every single citizen, not to that little isolated group, but to the 2,900,000 people who live under this Constitution. That is the gravamen of this Bill, and that is the gravamen of the offence which the Minister and the Executive Council are committing against the liberties of this people. They are making an excuse of what is, in my opinion, a mere sporadic outburst, which already, I believe, those who are guilty of have repented, deliberately to destroy what is written in the Constitution as one of the fundamental liberties of the people.

I condemn, and wholeheartedly condemn, the attacks upon the jurors. I condemn any man who takes the life of another without due and proper trial in open court before a jury of that man's countrymen. And because I do condemn it and because I reprobate it utterly, I am absolutely and bitterly opposed to this Bill. I say that this is a remedy which is bound to fail, that it is a Bill which is not justified in the excuse which has been made here for its introduction. No honest, right-thinking man in the country condones, in any way, the attacks upon the jurors. No significant section of the people support those who were engaged in them, and therefore the attacks upon the jurors ought not to be made the excuse for interfering with the rights of the vast majority of the citizens. If a mad dog were to run amok I do not think that any person would contend that it would be a proper remedy for that situation that the citizens as a whole should be maimed. Yet that is what the Minister who introduced this Bill proposes to do.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. G. O'Sullivan Mr. G. O'Sullivan
Speaker.P: No more than the other dog.

This is not muzzling any dog. This measure relates to the trial of certain prisoners, to men who are possibly being apprehended on suspicion and who, if they are brought to trial, must be brought to trial on evidence. I have not yet heard that those who are responsible for the attacks upon the jurors have been apprehended. This Bill does not propose to make it easier to apprehend or to detect those persons. It proposes to make it easier for the Executive to secure the conviction not only of those prisoners, ordinary or extraordinary, who offend against laws which have a political complexion, but of those who offend against laws which have a purely ethical justification. Irrespective of whatever class of law they offend against, this Bill is designed to make it easier for the Executive to secure the conviction of those people whom they wish to arraign before a judge and a packed jury.

The President has told the people of the world of the wonderful progress which we are making under his régime. This Bill is the finest example of that progress which could possibly be produced. Like a crab, it progresses backwards. It goes back, not merely to the age of Queen Anne but, in the words of the Minister for Justice himself, to the golden age of Justinian when jurors were swept away.

MainHeading.P: In introducing the Bill the Minister told us that it proposed to repeal a Statute passed about 1854, that it proposed, in his own words, to make the jury panel a confidential official document. Why should the Minister hold that out to the Dáil as a desirable thing? Surely if men are to be tried as they ought to be tried, in open court, before the eyes of the people, the people are entitled to know, apart altogether from the rights of the prisoner in the matter, the names of those who will constitute the jury which will deliver the verdict. It has been held that the publicity given to the jury panel is a very vital and a very important safeguard for the prisoner. The Minister for Justice himself admitted that though the right was only enjoyed in a certain limited way in England, it was yielded to the prisoner in the most important cases and in the most important issues upon which a citizen can be brought to trial. In England, though it may be withheld in a case of murder, though it may be withheld in other cases where a man is charged with crimes of dishonesty, in cases which have a political complexion, where an issue is to be tried out between a citizen on the one and and the Executive on the other, the right of scrutinising the jury panel is yielded freely to the prisoner. The Minister admitted that in cases of treason and misprision of treason, in these vitally important cases, the gravest crimes known to the English law, the prisoner is entitled to secure the publication of the jury panel.

Speaker.P: But not under the Constitution.

But in case of a like kind in this country the only justification which the Minister has for introducing this Bill is that here, where it is more important, possibly, than in England, in order that the confidence of all men may be established in the Executive and in the Judiciary, in order that those who have been divided most widely by bitter political differences may be taught and made to feel that they will secure justice in the courts of this country, the right which is yielded freely in England is, by this Bill, to be denied to its citizens.
Deputy O'Higgins accused us of speaking in this debate as though the only people in this country who matter were the prisoners.
It looks like it.

That is not an accurate representation of our attitude. There are other things to be considered. We say that not only do the prisoners matter, but other things matter. The due discharge of justice, the administration and the preservation of the law also matter. But above and over all, the great thing that matters is that justice should be done and that a man should be fairly and openly tried, that he should know beforehand those before whom he will be arraigned, that he may have an opportunity of scrutinising the panel of jurors, that that panel may not be constituted without his knowledge in such a way that there may be included upon it persons, possibly unknown to him, who, because of some political, business or family feud, some difference of religion or of political principle, may be so prejudiced that they may not be able to yield him a fair trial. Men's minds are often so warped that even by the exercise of their will they are unable to adjudicate fairly on some issues. Therefore it is of the utmost importance that the fullest publicity should be given to the jury panel, so that——
——they should be shot.

That is an excellent exemplification of the attitude of the Minister and of the Minister's supporters in this matter—if a man differs from them they believe he should be shot. A number of them have shot men that have differed from them, without even the appearance of the mock trial that is going to be afforded under this Bill. The point I was making was this, that it was quite possible that there would be included on a jury panel the names of people unknown to the accused, who, because of some political or religious difference or other affiliation of theirs would not be capable of doing justice between him and the State. There are in this country of ours, unfortunately, two secret organisations. One, I believe, is established on a definitely religious basis; the other is established on at least a non-sectarian basis. Supposing the Grand Panjandrum of one of these organisations, for some reason or other, has incurred the enmity of the Executive of this State, and they decide to bring him to trial, how better could they secure his conviction than by seeing that the jury panel was constituted of members of the rival secret organisation? The person brought to trial might be utterly unaware that the members of the jury panel were members of the rival organisation. None of them would be known to him either by name or by sight, and yet they certainly would be, I believe, incapable of giving him a fair trial under certain circumstances. It possibly would depend upon the charge in the indictment, but, if the jury panel were published, it would be then open to the accused's friends, with their wider knowledge of men, to come and point out the names of men on that jury panel who, because of their known associations, would be incapable of giving him that fair trial, and they would put him in a position to object in open court to the inclusion of such men in the jury empanelled to try him.

I would like to point out that not only is the panel to be a confidential document, but the very identities of the jurymen are to be lost. Their names are to be kept secret, divulged to no independent man, not even to the prisoner; they are to be known only to those officials of the Executive who are charged with the conduct of the trial and prosecution. Every precaution is to be taken to ensure that that secrecy is preserved. The jury is to be summoned by stealth—summoned by post. The jurors are to notify their attendance by stealth. Not once are the chosen agents of the Executive to appear in the light of open day.

MainHeading.P: Under Section 4 of the Minister's offspring they are to come early in the morning, to whisper their names to a certain functionary of the court, and then they are to depart, no man knowing whence they came, no man knowing whither they are going. No man to challenge whether they are honest citizens or ruffians. You can picture them stealing away, coming to the court early in the morning like members of an Italian conspiracy, or of the Ku Klux Klan and whispering to the officer of the court that the conspiracy is all complete, that the bravadoes are all present and ready so that the trial may now proceed. In what country except this, under what Executive except this, would such an atmosphere of conspiracy be permitted to pollute the courts of justice? Not even when the prisoner is arraigned is he going to know the names of the men who are about to try him. Those names are to be kept secret. Under Section 4 (d) of this Bill we read: “...every person attending the court as a juror shall be called, addressed, and referred to for all purposes in the court solely by the number by which he is distinguished on the panel of jurors from which he is drawn and no such person shall be called, addressed, or referred to in the court by his name, nor shall the address or description of any such person be called or mentioned in the court.”

Every precaution is to be taken to ensure that the names of those persons who are empanelled to try the issue between the Executive, on the one hand, and the citizens on the other, will be kept secret from the people of this State. The jury is no longer to be constituted of twelve citizens, but of twelve cyphers— twelve changing and unstable cyphers, of uncertain and unascertainable identity—with no precaution and no safeguard, as Deputy Boland pointed out, to ensure that the same juror, or batch of jurors, who have proved themselves the ready and pliable instruments of the Executive, will not be empanelled over and over again, under varying numbers, to try those prisoners whose conviction the Executive wishes to ensure. It may be said that that is possibly an extravagant construction to put upon the section, but it is quite clear from the Bill that that sort of procedure can take place. This Bill opens the way to that abuse, and once the way is opened a hard-pressed Executive is sure to take advantage of the facility offered for that sort of thing by this Bill.
